tasks.task: Farmer detailing his farming journey and methods.
subtasks: Describe starting farming in 1996 with 20 acres from father.
Mention collaboration with father in farming since 1996 until father's passing a year ago.
Explain adoption of no-till farming in 1988 influenced by Dr. Duane Beck.
Recall struggles with wet spots using chisel plow and field cultivation.
Describe switching to rotary hoe method and its drawbacks.
Explain transition to a permanent three-field rotation in 2013-14.
Highlight the impact of the three-field rotation on wet spots and soil health.
Advise on transitioning to no-till gradually rather than all at once.
Discuss the benefits of integrating small grains and cover crops for soil structure.
Address skepticism about small grain profitability and emphasize yield benefits in rotation.

tasks.task: Farmer discussing soil erosion and farming methods over the years.
subtasks: Reveal initial problems with soil erosion and efforts to address them.
Narrate the use of chisel plow and field cultivation for wet areas but noting ineffective results.
Explain the switch from the chisel plow to a rotary hoe for wet spots.
Describe the unintended consequences of using the rotary hoe.
Reflect on the introduction of a three-way rotation with oats in 2013-14.

tasks.task: Farmer sharing advice on transitioning to no-till farming.
subtasks: Advise farmers not to switch the entire farm to no-till immediately.
Suggest a progressive approach, starting field by field.
Highlight the benefits of small grains and cover cropping in soil health.
Encourage integrating livestock and cover crops for accelerated soil improvement.

tasks.task: Farmer discussing the three-field rotation impact on wet spots.
subtasks: Explain the reduction in wet spots due to the three-field rotation.
Discuss the persistence of some wet spots even after the rotation.
Share insights on the time needed for soil improvement from no-till methods.

tasks.task: Farmer addressing perceptions about small grains and profitability.
subtasks: Challenge the notion that small grains can't be profitable.
Emphasize the need for better marketing when farming small grains.
Highlight the yield benefits of the three-field rotation.
Reinforce that the third crop in the rotation can compensate for potential small grain losses.
